Let $a,$ $b,$ $c$ be real numbers such that
\[|ax^2 + bx + c| \le 1\]for all $0 \le x \le 1.$  Find the largest possible value of $|a| + |b| + |c|.$

1.subquestion: Consider the discriminant of the quadratic equation $ax^2 + bx+c=0$ when $x = \dfrac{-b}{2a}.$

subanswer.text: The discriminant is $b^2 - 4ac.$ Substituting $x = \dfrac{-b}{2a}$, the quadratic equation becomes $\left(\dfrac{a}{4}\right) \left( \dfrac{b}{a} \right)^2 + \dfrac{b}{a} + c=0.$ So the discriminant is $\left( \dfrac{b}{2a} \right)^2 - \dfrac{4c}{a^2}.$ The answer is $\left( \dfrac{b}{2a} \right)^2 - \dfrac{4c}{a^2}$.
